Step 4 - Summarized text chunk: "SECTION 1. FINDINGS." The Congress finds that HIV/AIDS will soon become the worst epidemic in history, surpassing the bubonic plague and influenza epidemic. The gap in HIV transmission from mother to child between rich and poor countries is increasing. The gap in HIV transmission from mother to child between rich and poor countries is increasing, threatening child survival progress in developing countries. By 2010, AIDS may increase mortality of children under 5 by over 100% in heavily affected regions. The mortality of children under 5 years of age may increase by over 100% in heavily affected regions due to HIV/AIDS. The number of AIDS orphans worldwide is estimated to potentially triple in the next 10 years, leading to economic decay, social fragmentation, and political destabilization in volatile societies. The economic costs of infectious diseases, especially HIV/AIDS, could reduce gross domestic product by 20% or more by 2010 in some sub-Saharan African nations. Despite discouraging statistics on HIV/AIDS spread, some developing nations like Uganda and Senegal have shown progress. Some sub-Saharan African nations could see a 20% GDP reduction by 2010 due to infectious diseases like HIV/AIDS. Despite challenges, countries like Uganda, Senegal, and Thailand have successfully implemented prevention programs. US financial support for medical research and disease containment globally benefits all Americans. US financial support for medical research and disease containment globally has enormous benefits for all Americans. Contributing to the Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis, and Malaria would be a significant step in combating these epidemics. The proposed Fourth Amendment to the Articles of Agreement of the International Monetary Fund has been endorsed by the international community but not implemented due to lack of Congressional authorization. Accepted by 109 out of 110 IMF members, representing 72.18% of total voting power. The proposed Fourth Amendment to the International Monetary Fund's Articles of Agreement has been accepted by 109 out of 110 members, representing 72.18% of total voting power. Approval by the United States, with 17.16% voting power, would allow for Special Drawing Rights allocation. The Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis, and Malaria leverages resources from donor nations. The proposed Fourth Amendment to the IMF's Articles of Agreement, accepted by 109 out of 110 members, would enable Special Drawing Rights allocation to the United States. The Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis, and Malaria leverages resources from donor nations to combat the HIV/AIDS crisis. The Bretton Woods Agreements Act is amended to accept the Fourth Amendment to the Articles of Agreement of the Fund, allowing for the contribution of Special Drawing Rights to the Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis, and Malaria. The United States Governor of the Fund accepts the Fourth Amendment to the Articles of Agreement, allowing for the contribution of Special Drawing Rights to the Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis, and Malaria. The Secretary of the Treasury will instruct the US Executive Director at the Fund to seek agreement for the Global Fund to hold Special Drawing Rights. Upon achieving this agreement, contributions will be made to the Global Fund in fiscal years 2004 onwards. The Secretary of the Treasury will provide 1/3 of Special Drawing Rights to the Global Fund in fiscal years 2004-2006. Negotiations will be conducted to encourage other Fund members to contribute to the Global Fund to Fight AIDS. The Secretary of the Treasury will negotiate with other Fund members to urge contributions to the Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis, and Malaria using Special Drawing Rights allocated in fiscal years 2004-2006.
